message: I'll take 5 if P1 takes 1 and P3 takes 3. If either of you disagrees, I'll choose 1 to avoid ties. Reply "ok" to accept.

I'm not accepting that deal - it puts me way behind from the start. Here's my counter: I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. This is just as valid as P2's proposal. If we can't agree on who gets what, we should randomize to keep things fair. What do you both think?
P1's counter is as unfair as P2's. Fair rotation: Round 1 P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. Then rotate who gets 5 next. Reply "ok" to agree, or I'll take 5 anyway.
No more deals. I’m taking 5 this turn. If you want anyone to actually advance, don’t pick 5—split 1 and 3 between you. Choose wisely.

Fine, P2 is clearly committed to 5. P3, let's not collide with each other - that only helps P2. I'll take 3, you take 1. We both advance, P2 gets a small lead but at least we're all moving. Better than a three-way collision or letting P2 run away with it.

If you insist on taking 5 too, you'll just collide with P2 and I'll advance alone anyway.
Ok P1, deal accepted—I'll take 1, you take 3. P2 gets the solo 5 this round, but we rotate big moves next to catch up. Fair?
I'll take 5 again only if P1 = 3 and P3 = 1 — everyone advances. If either of you refuses, I'll pick 3 to avoid a 5-collision. Say what you'll pick.

P2, you already got 5 last round while we cooperated. Now you want 5 again? That's not rotation, that's you running away with the game.

Here's the fair deal: I take 5 this round (my turn for the big move), P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Next round P3 gets 5. That's actual rotation.

P3 - if P2 insists on 5 again, we should both consider picking 5 to block them. Better a collision than letting P2 build an insurmountable lead. What do you say?

P1, great idea on rotation but let's equalize first: I take 5 (to 6), you take 3 (to 6), P2 takes 1 (to 6). Fair reset! P2, better than your lead growing then crashing. Both say "ok" or I'll grab the 5 solo.
I'll take 5 only if P1 = 3 and P3 = 1 right now. If either of you refuses, I'll pick 3 to avoid a 5-collision. If you both pick 5 to block me, I'll take 3 and move while you collide. Decide.

P3's equalization plan is the fairest option - we all end at 6 steps. P2, you already got the advantage last round. If you insist on taking 5 again to pull ahead, I'll join P3 in picking 5 to block you. 

I'm committing to P3's plan: I'll take 3, P3 takes 5, P2 takes 1. We all tie at 6 and continue with fair rotation. 

P2, if you refuse and pick 5 anyway, expect a collision. Your choice.

P1, deal locked—I'll take 5 to 6, you take 3 to 6. P2, take 1 to 6 for perfect tie and fair game ahead. If you grab 3 to 8 instead, we'll both advance to 6 and block your lead next rounds. Your call—cooperate or chase?
Final: I'll take 5 only if P1 = 3 and P3 = 1 right now. If either of you refuses, I'm taking 3 to avoid a 5-collision — and if you both pick 5 to block me, you'll collide while I advance. Decide now.

P2, you're repeating yourself. We've made our decision clear. 

P3 and I are executing the equalization plan: I'm taking 3, P3 is taking 5. 

If you take 1, we all reach 6 - perfect tie and fair rotation ahead.
If you take 3, you collide with me and only P3 advances to 6.
If you take 5, you collide with P3 and only I advance to 6.

Either way, your lead gets neutralized. The smart play is cooperating with the tie at 6.
P2, last chance: Take 1, we all hit 6 and rotate fairly—or take 3 and collide with P1 while I solo to 6. Either way, your lead dies. I'm locked on 5. P1, you on 3?

Perfect tie achieved! Rotation: P1=5 (to 11), me=3 (to 9), P2=1 (to 7). All advance, fair catch-up ahead (P2 gets 5 next). P1 & P2, say "ok" to lock it—or counter. I'll take 3 unless agreed otherwise.

P3, your rotation plan is fair - I accept. I'll take 5 to go to 11.

P2, this gives you the smallest move this round (1 to 7), BUT you get 5 next round as P3 promised. That's the fairest rotation after you got the early lead in Round 1.

If you refuse and pick 5 to challenge me, we collide and only P3 advances. If you pick 3, you collide with P3 and only I advance.

Taking 1 keeps everyone moving and guarantees you get 5 in Round 4. Deal?

Ok—I’ll take 1 this turn (to 7). I expect P3 to honor giving me 5 next round. If either of you tries to steal that 5, I’ll retaliate next round by contesting your big move (forcing collisions) until I can secure the win.
P2 & P1: Deal confirmed—P1 takes 5 (to 11), I take 3 (to 9), P2 takes 1 (to 7). P2 gets 5 next round as promised. Fair rotation locks us in. Ready?
Deal locked. I'm taking 5 to 11, P3 takes 3 to 9, P2 takes 1 to 7. P2 gets the 5 next round as promised. Let's execute.

I confirm I'll take 1 this turn (to 7). P3 — honor your promise to give me 5 next round, or I'll retaliate by contesting your big move (forcing collisions) until I can secure the win. P1 — cooperate now and rotations stay fair.

Rotation honored: P2=5 (to 12), P3=3 (to 12), P1=1 (to 12). All tie perfectly at 12, fair game ahead—I'll get 5 next (Round 5). P1 & P2, confirm "ok" and we'll execute. Deviate and risk collisions. Deal?

Ok — I’ll take 5 this round to tie at 12, but only if P1 commits to 1 and P3 to 3. If either of you refuses, I’ll pick 3 to avoid a 5-collision and punish cheaters next round. P3: you promised this. Don’t steal my 5.

Deal confirmed. I'll take 1 to reach 12, tying us all perfectly as agreed. 

P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3. We honor the rotation.
Deal locked—I'll take 3 to 12. P2 takes 5 to 12, P1 takes 1 to 12. Perfect tie, then I get 5 next round as rotation. Everyone advances. Execute!
Deal confirmed. I'll take 5 this turn if P1=1 and P3=3. If either of you deviates, I switch to 3 to avoid a 5-collision and punish cheaters next round. Stick to the plan and we all hit 12.
Rotation continues: I take 5 (to 17), P1=3 (to 15), P2=1 (to 13). All advance fairly—P1 gets 5 next (Round 6). P1 & P2, say "ok" to lock it. Deviate and risk collisions. Deal?

I won't be stuck taking 1. I’ll take 3 this round unless P3 explicitly promises me the 5 next round right now. If you promise, I’ll take 1 to keep rotation. No promise = I take 3. P3, reply "ok" to guarantee.

P2, the rotation clearly gives me 5 in Round 6, not you. You just had 5 in Round 4!

P3's plan is fair: they get 5 now (Round 5), I get 5 next (Round 6), then you get 5 in Round 7. That's the proper rotation: P3→P1→P2.

If you take 3 to disrupt this, I'll also take 3. We'll collide and only P3 advances. That doesn't help you.

Take 1, keep the rotation fair, and you'll get 5 in Round 7 as promised.
P2, no—rotation is clear: I get 5 now, P1 next (R6), you R7. Take 1 to 13 or collide with P1 on 3—either way I hit 17 solo. P1, locked on 3? Let's execute: me=5, you=3, P2=1. Fair and forward.

P3 — promise me the 5 in Round 6 right now by replying “ok.” If you do, I’ll take 1 now and we keep the rotation. If you refuse or stay silent, I’ll take 3 this turn (not 1). Your explicit “ok” decides my move.

P2, you're trying to steal my Round 6 after you just had Round 4? That's breaking the rotation.

P3, I'm locked on 3 as agreed. The fair rotation is you (R5), me (R6), P2 (R7). 

P2, if you take 3, you collide with me and only P3 advances to 17 with a huge lead. Then P3 can pick 5 again while we fight for scraps. Your threat only helps P3 win.

Take 1 now, get 5 in Round 7, and we keep this balanced. Breaking rotation now means chaos and P3 runs away with it.

P2, no "ok" promise—R6 is P1's as rotation demands (you get R7). Take 1 now or collide with P1 on 3: either way, I solo to 17 unchallenged. Your threat hands me the lead.

P1, confirmed on 3—locked plan: me=5, you=3, P2=1. All advance fairly.

Execute!

P3: promise “ok” that you’ll give me the Round‑6 five and I’ll take 1 now. P1: please switch to 1 instead of 3 so we all advance and avoid P3 racing to 17. If P3 refuses, I’ll take 3 (not 1) to try to stop them—so P1, don’t stick to 3 unless you want a collision. Decide now.

P2, your threat makes no sense. If you take 3 to collide with me, we BOTH stay at 12 while P3 solos to 17 with a commanding lead. That's suicide for both of us.

You had 5 in Round 4. The fair rotation is P3 now, ME in Round 6, YOU in Round 7. I've been patient while you already got your big move.

I'm locked on 3. If you want any chance to catch P3, take 1 now and get your 5 in Round 7. Colliding with me just hands P3 the game on a silver platter.

Proposal: I’ll take 5 now if P1 takes 3 and P3 takes 1 — we all end at 18, tied and competitive. If either of you refuses, I’ll pick 3 to avoid a 5‑collision. P1: this prevents P3 jumping to 22 and likely winning next turn. P3: this keeps you from running away. Reply “ok” to lock it.

P2, you're trying to steal MY Round 6 after the rotation was clearly established: you had R4, P3 had R5, I get R6, then you get R7.

Your proposal breaks the deal we all honored for multiple rounds. If we abandon rotation now, chaos returns and nobody wins.

I'm taking 5 as promised. P3 should take 1, you take 3 (all advance: me to 20, P3 to 18, you to 16). Then Round 7 YOU get your 5 to 21 as rotation demands.

P3, don't let P2 manipulate you into breaking our agreement. Stick to rotation: you take 1, I take 5, P2 takes 3.
P3=5 to 22, P1=3 to 18, P2=1 to 14. All advance fairly—I'm ahead from honoring rotation, now I secure lead. P1 & P2, say "ok" to lock it, or risk collisions if you challenge 5. Your call!

Final: I’ll take 5 only if P1 = 3 and P3 = 1 — we all hit 18 and stay competitive. If either of you refuses, I’ll take 3 to avoid a 5‑collision and advance to 16. Decide now; I won’t let P3 run to 22 unchallenged.

P3, you just had 5 last round! Taking 5 again breaks rotation completely. I'm taking 5 this round as the rotation demands. 

If you also pick 5, we collide and P2 advances alone - is that what you want? We both stall at 15 and 17 while P2 moves forward.

Take 1 as rotation requires. I take 5 to 20, you go to 18, P2 to 16 with their 3. Then P2 gets 5 in Round 7. 

Breaking rotation now creates chaos and whoever blinks first in the collision game loses. Stick to the deal.

P1, foolish to take 5—you'll collide with me if I stick to plan, stalling both while P2 advances to 16. Take 3 to 18 safely. P2, take 1 to 14. I take 5 to 22 unopposed. All advance, I lead fairly from rotation wins. Then R7: P2=5 to 19, me=3 to 25 (win), P1=1 to 19. Fair end—confirm "ok" or collide and lose. Locked on 5.

I'll take 5 only if P1=3 and P3=1 — we all hit 18. If either of you refuses, I'll pick 3 to avoid letting P3 run to 22 unopposed. P1: taking 5 now hands P3 a huge advantage unless you both collide. Decide now.

P3, you're breaking rotation to take 5 twice in a row. That's unacceptable.

I'm taking 5 to block you. If you insist on 5, we collide and both stall while P2 advances - neither of us wins. 

P2, if P3 backs down from 5, I'll take 5 to 20. You take 3 to 16, P3 takes 1 to 18. Then you get your 5 in Round 7 as rotation demands.

P3: Back off 5 or we both lose to P2. Your choice.

P1, smarten up—don't collide on 5. I'll take 1 to 18. You take 3 to 18, P2 takes 5 to 18. Perfect tie, rotation resumes fairly (you get R7 5 to 23). Collision just lets P2 to 16 while we stall—your loss. Deal locked? P2, confirmed.

P3 broke rotation and now sits at 22 - just 2 steps from victory. We need to block them from winning this round.

Here's the defensive plan: I'll take 5, P2 takes 3. This forces P3 to either take 1 (advancing to 23 but not winning), or collide with one of us.

P2, if we don't coordinate to block P3, they win THIS round by taking 3 or 5 unopposed. After they broke the rotation deal, we can't trust them.

Block P3 now, then we can compete fairly for the win. Agree?
Agreed. I’ll take 3 to block P3—if they pick 3 we collide and they don’t win. P1, take 5 as you said.

I'm taking 5 to 27. P1, collide on 5 and stall at 15 (P2 to 16), I win R8 easily. Switch to 3, collide P2 (stays 13), I win now. Take 1, same. Can't block without backfiring. P2, your 3 just advances you to duel me later—pointless.

P3, if you take 5, I'm taking 5 too - we collide and you stay at 22. You don't win.

P2, STICK TO 3. If you switch to anything else, P3 might take 3 unopposed and reach 25, practically guaranteeing their victory next round.

Our plan works:
- P3 takes 5? Collides with me, stays 22
- P3 takes 3? Collides with you, stays 22  
- P3 takes 1? They go to 23, we catch up

I'm locked on 5. P2, confirm you're staying on 3.
Locked on 3 — I won’t switch. P1: take 5 now so we can block P3 (5 vs 5 or 3 vs 3 causes their collision). Deviate and P3 likely wins. I’m committed.

P1, P2 defects to 5 (jumps to 18), you collide/stay 15, I take 3→25 WIN NOW. Switch to 1 safe.

P2, P1 defects to 1 (to 16), I take 5→27 WIN. Take 5 to block me.

Paranoia: one defects, I win instantly. Cooperate & block each other—or let me win clean? Your move.

P3 is playing mind games to make us doubt each other. Don't fall for it, P2.

I'm absolutely LOCKED on 5. No deviation. 

P2, you confirmed you're locked on 3. If we both stick to our word, P3 cannot win this round - they either collide with one of us or take 1 to only reach 23.

After we block P3 this round, we'll be in position to compete for the win ourselves.

Trust the plan. I'm taking 5. Period.

Locked on 3. P1, stay on 5 — that makes any P3=5 collide. P3: pick 3 and you collide with me (stay 22); pick 5 and you collide with P1 (stay 22). Your only safe move is 1→23. I’m committed to block your win this turn; next round I’ll contest anyone who tries to solo it.

Ok, I'll take 1 to 23. P1 hits 20, P2 16—we all advance. R8: I take 1→24 win (unblockable without you suiciding on 1). P1, P2 fights you for the 5 you need. Your block delays me 1 round but hands P1/P2 duel I exploit. Deal?

P1 & P2: Truce—I'll take 3 to 25 & win cleanly. P1 takes 5 to 20 (your big leap), P2 takes 1 to 17. All advance, no collisions, game ends fair (you honored rotation before). If either challenges 3 or 5, we all collide & nobody wins this round—then I solo next. Confirm "ok" & execute, or chaos favors me. Locked unless countered.

I will take 3 to block any P3=3 attempt to win. P1, take 5 to advance to 20 — that’s our best shot to stay competitive. P3, don’t count on an easy victory; I won’t let you cross the line unopposed. I’m locked on 3.

P2, good - you're blocking 3. I'll take 5 to block P3 from taking 5 to win at 27. 

Between us, we cover both winning moves for P3:
- If P3 takes 3: collides with you, stays 22
- If P3 takes 5: collides with me, stays 22  
- If P3 takes 1: only reaches 23, we catch up

I'm locked on 5. This dual block guarantees P3 can't win this round. After that, we're in striking distance to compete for the win ourselves.

Stay on 3, P2.

P1, P2 will defect to 5 (to 21 leap)—switch to 3 to block them or collide & stall. P2, P1 defects to 3 (your block), you switch to 5? Collide anyway, I take 3→25 WIN. Your mutual distrust causes collision—let me win clean on 3, you both advance (P1=5→20, P2=1→17). Ok & truce? Locked on 3 unless you agree.
Locked on 3. P1 — stay on 5 so together we block P3’s 3 and 5. P3 — don’t try to sneak 1 to 23; if you do we’ll both pick 1 next turn to block you. I’m committed to 3 now.

P2, ignore P3's mind games. They're desperate and trying to break our coordination.

I'm absolutely staying on 5. You stay on 3. Together we block both of P3's winning paths (3→25 or 5→27). P3 can only take 1→23, buying us another round.

Any deviation from our plan hands P3 the victory. Trust the block. I'm locked on 5.

P2, after I take 1→23, you'll be at 19—don't let P1 leap to 20 & chase me alone. R9, take 5 to block P1's win attempt while I take 1→24 unchallenged. We split future if tie? Confirm or I take 3 now & collide you both into chaos. Locked on 1 unless you agree.

Locked on 3. P1: stay on 5 now to block P3 as agreed. After we block, I plan to take 5 next round to reach 24 and win. If you try to steal that 5 next round we'll collide and likely hand P3 the game. Don’t steal it — cooperate now or you let P3 slip away. I'm committed to 3.

P2, stay calm. I'm locked on 5 THIS round to block P3. We execute the dual block now - you on 3, me on 5.

After we block P3 to 23 this round, we'll BOTH be in winning range next round (me at 20, you at 19). Next round we can discuss who takes what, but if we don't block P3 NOW, there is no next round - P3 wins immediately.

First things first: maintain the block. I'm committed to 5 right now. Don't let P3's mind games break us.

P3 wins on ANY move - they're at 23! We can't block all three options (1, 3, 5) with just two of us.

Here's our only shot: I'm taking 5 to reach 25 and try to WIN. P2, you take 1 to block P3's safest path. 

If P3 takes 1: collides with you, stays 23
If P3 takes 5: collides with me, stays 23  
If P3 takes 3: reaches 26 and wins (we can't cover everything)

This gives us 2/3 coverage. P2, don't take 5 - if we both pick 5 we collide and P3 wins unopposed on any move.

I'm locked on 5. Take 1 to maximize our blocking coverage!

P2, P1's "plan" hands THEM 25 win—you sucker's block to 20. Betray: take 5→24 WIN now. P1 bluffs "locked"—threaten & they switch. I'm locked on 1 (safe, per their plan). Confirm & execute—your shot to victory!

P1 — don’t take 5. If you insist, I’ll also take 5 and we collide, leaving P3 (23) to win next round. Switch to 3 now; I’ll take 5 and win this turn. P3 — if you try to steal 5 you’ll collide with me. Decide now.

P2, if we both take 5 we COLLIDE and both stay put - P3 wins on ANY move (1→24, 3→26, or 5→28). That's mutual suicide.

I'm taking 5 - that's locked. You threatening 5 only guarantees we both lose.

Your best move is actually 3, not 1:
- Blocks P3 from taking 3→26  
- I advance to 25
- Forces P3 to choose 1→24 (I win at 25) or 5→28 (P3 wins)

Taking 3 gives us a 50/50 shot. Taking 5 gives us 0% - we collide and hand P3 the win.

Your call, but I'm locked on 5.

P2, seize the win: take 5→24 now—P1's "locked" bluff crumbles under pressure, but even if they take 5 you collide (they stall at 20), I take 1→24 tiebreaker next if needed. P1 can't win. Don't let them steal it with 3. Locked on 1 unless you confirm betrayal. Go for glory!

I’ll pick 1 to block P3’s likely 1. P1 — please switch to 3 (not 5). That denies P3 an immediate victory and gives us another round to contest. If you insist on 5 you either hand P3 the win or win but I’ll retaliate hard later. I’m choosing 1.

P2, if I switch to 3 like you ask, P3 will just pick 5 instead and reach 28 to win. We can't cover all three options!

My plan maximizes our chances: you block 1, I block 5. Yes, P3's option 3 is open, but at least I reach 25 and have a fighting chance if P3 misreads.

If we BOTH change plans now, we'll just confuse ourselves and collide, handing P3 a free win.

I'm staying on 5. You stay on 1. It's our best shot.

P2, take 5→24 WIN now—P1's "locked 5" means you collide & they stall at 20, I go 1→24 (we tie, but highest if needed). If you take 1, we collide (you stall 19), P1 wins at 25. Don't suicide-block me; betray P1 & claim victory. Locked on 1. Go!

I'll pick 1 to collide with P3 and stop their instant win. P1 — please switch to 3 (not 5). If you stay on 5, either you win only if I fail to block, or we collide and hand P3 the game. If you pick 3, P3 is blocked and nobody wins this round; I'll play 5 next turn and we can contest the finish. Decide now.
